Smartphone Awards 2020 Hosted by Marques Brownlee

Best Big Smartphone: Xiaomi Mi 10 Ultra
Best Compact Smartphone: iPhone 12 Mini (Samsung Galaxy Z Flip mentioned but not awarded)
Best Camera Smartphone: iPhone 12 Pro Max
Best Battery: Asus ROG Phone 3
Best Smartphone Design: Samsung Galaxy Note 20 Ultra
Best Budget Smartphone: Google Pixel 4A (Runner Up: iPhone SE 2020)
Biggest Bust of the Year: Samsung Galaxy Note 20 (Escobar Fold 2 Mentioned)
Most Improved Phone: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 (Honorably Mentioned: Google Pixel 5)
Phone of the Year: Samsung Galaxy S20 FE (One Plus 8 Pro and iPhone 12 Pro mentioned)

Award Counts

Samsung Awards: 4 = Samsung Galaxy Note 20 Ultra,Samsung Galaxy Note 20, Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2, Samsung Galaxy S20 FE
Apple Awards: 2 = iPhone 12 Mini, iPhone 12 Pro Max
Asus Awards: 1= Asus ROG Phone 3
Google Awards: 1 = Google Pixel 4A
Xiaomi Awards: 1 = Xiaomi Mi 10 Ultra

Smartphone Mentions
Samsung: 1 = Samsung Galaxy Flip Z
Apple: 2 = iPhone SE 2020, iPhone 12 Pro
Google: 1 = Google Pixel 5
Escobar: 1 = Escobar Fold 2
OnePlus: 1 = One Plus 8 Pro
The End.

Disappointed with the budget category to be honest. They aren't budget phones they are mid tier phones. The way I see it you got budget (people who need a phone but are legitimately hard up), mid tier, high tier and then the hyperphones if you will. $400 is not a budget phone imo, not when you can get a perfectly passable experience for $200.

@Cyka Blyat Not true. Old flagships will only get slower depending upon how frequent software updates occur. I had bought a flagship, 2 years after launch. It had overheating and battery issues and didn't last even 3 years. Currently I'm using a 230 dollar phone and it has already exceeded 3 years of use without any issues. I can easily squeeze an extra year with it. So even a well made budget phone can exceed an old flagship.
@Cyka Blyat wow ur dumb. Samsung and Motorola both make 200 dollar phones and they are very good brands

$200 phone doesnt really cut it, no 1st tier smartphone company will make one, which leaves you 2nd tier options that wont last, or are full of bloatware. im in the group of being a value shopper for a smartphone i like getting the most bang for your buck and nothing really beats buying a 2-3 year old flagship or niche brand, mid-tier etc. paying for a $200 brand new phone today is getting what you pay for. buying a 2 year old "new" phone is getting more than what you paid for becuase you didn't pay for the depreciation of a new phone that everyone is jumping into.

@MrYellow Neither does the premium, though. If a $200 phone is good enough for 2-3 years and the $1,200 caps out around 5 years the $200 would easily prove it's worth. I have the previous SE, and it's pretty bleh but it's still over $400CAD to replace. I'm not buying a new one every few years. I'm keeping mine till it dies most likely. Of couse how you define passable, good enough, or even premium is a huge difference. But I agree that he should've hit the $200 price range. In general it would be nice to have a best per price range from bottom to top rather than a budget category.

Follow up 2: Also the selector of panelist can't be the judge himself or if he participates, he'll vote only if there's a tie in scores given by panel. Ofcourse he'll share his opinion for all selections while hosting.
Follow up to the idea - These 5 panelists can be changed partially each year. That keeps the team of panelists from developing a bias to/against a brand.

It still makes me pretty mad that every big youtuber described the pixel 4 as the biggest disappointment of the year. I have this phone and i freaking love it. So much of you want a compact phone with flagship specs and it's like te best option to go. It has OLED with 90hz, best snapdragon of last year, some of the best if not the best stereo speakers and most important awesome cameras. So many complains cause it lacks ultrawide but as i have it for so long, the 2X portait zoom is so much more useful. Now when pixel 5 has ultrawide it takes much worse potrait pictures cause it crops the main sensor except use its own 2x optical zoom. And pixel's take best portait shots on the market. Awesome software, small body, amazing cameras and specs... and biggest failure ? Because of the small battery ? EVERY COMPACT PHONE HAS SMALL BATTERY. iphone se, iphone 12 mini, galaxy s10e. But none of them has 90hz. If you switch if off it will last far longer than the competition with similar capacity. I forced 90hz but i use darkmode everywhere and not so hight brightness and i finish the day with 20 sometimes 30 % with 4H SOT. face id works great. if i don't cover my nose with the mask it unlocks it which i love. Bevore pixel i've had p30 pro and oneplus 7 pro. All of them where great but freakin big. Pixel has all what matters and the small  size. Totally love it.

Shout out to the Samsung S20 FE! I got mine on release day via T-Mobile trade in. I upgraded from an S7, and while my S20 FE does suffer from the occasional screen issue, I could not be happier. It's wicked fast, and I can use it all day and end at 50% battery. At the time of writing, T-Mobile has the same deal running they offered back in October: $500 off for trading in an eligible device, which is basically any flagship from Apple, Samsung, or Google going back 4 years. That means I managed to upgrade my S7 with its fading battery to an S20 FE for just $200!

(AT&T and Verizon currently have somewhat similar deals running, but they often requiring adding a new line or expensive unlimited plans. I could upgrade on T-Mobile without it affecting my plan.)

I don't know if I all got duds or Apple is just really crappy. From what I noticed, Apple is a money laundering scheme. They design the devices to work for maybe 2 years. And to cover themselves, they have a limited one year warranty. So if something does go wrong in the one year, the issue probably doesnt fall into the category to get fixed or get your money back. But back to the story. Apple designs their products to last maybe two years to force you to buy the next generation. The few people that get there iPhone 6s to last to when the iPhone 12 is released, rarely exist. That just shows that apple can't make reliable phones. Apple even has lawsuits of slowly phasing out older phones through updates, to get their loyal customers to fall into the two year trap. The sooner you realize that Apple is awful the better. And the only reason why people use Apple is because it has fancy colors, and it is trendy/chic millennial go with the flow crap. It's just annoying how they are the only phone brand that feels entitled enough to use a whole different charging cord. When literally the rest of the phone universe is onto USBC. Call this a biased rant, or spitting straight facts. But I don't like apple and the sooner you realize Apple is a money laundering scheme, the better.

Marques as much as I want to like your videos, sometimes I question why your opinions stray so far away from the industry norm. I understand picking your favorites in more subjective categories, but when it comes to objective things such as the best camera of the year and you're picking an iPhone, I just wonder what goes through your mind. The P40 Pro, the Xperia 1ii, Mate 40 Pro and above all the MI 10 Ultra absolutely destroy the iPhone, and the MI is widely considered to be the best camera available on a smartphone today. You have to take into consideration ALL that goes into a camera, like shooting 4k 60fps with amazing electronic stabilization on the MI 10 Ultra's selfie camera, or the 10x optical zoom in the Huawei's, the AI processing and night modes, the Xperia 1 II pro features, etc. Not just how "editable" the pictures are from an iPhone. Sometimes your apple bias just makes your videos unbearable, and I mean that in the best possible way.

I actually bought the Samsung S20 FE this year!😄
It was between that one and the 8T / 8 Pro. Can't remember why I went for the Samsung instead of the OnePlus...

Personal opinion of the S20 FE:
Great phone, but two bad things. Battery + charging and software experience.
I went from a Huawei Mate 20 Pro, which had EVERYTHING when it came out. The phones that came out this year doesn't really have any big differences from what we got back then (it came out in winter 2018), the newer phones just got better specs from that time. So everything on the S20 is upgraded from the Mate 20, the camera is way better, higher refresh rate, a little bit faster etc.
Not used to the software quite iyet, I felt like Huawei did it better, but I can't really put a word on why... And the battery is horrible compared to Huawei, it lasts MAX a day. Mate 20 pro could last up to two full days. And the charging is slow, it's like 25W, while the Mate 20 from 2 years ago is doing 40W. There are phones out there that are doing way more wirelessly...

Didn't know that battery life and charging meant so much to me after it got downgraded, but now I know!

I think a budget phone absolutely needed a headphone jack a couple years ago. Now, thanks to Apple's courage (yeah, I mean it), decent bluetooth headphones are mainstream and sold for peanuts.

if there was an Underrated phone of the year award - it would be the Lg V60. It's a midlevel phone, not a flagship, but has the specs and feature set that competes with flagships. It also has the dual screen case specifically designed for it that gives it some unique modern touches with great practical application and the ability to "choose" to use that application or just use the midlevel phone design. Finally it has a quad DAC and headphone jack giving it a niche market in audiophiles on the go and just people who just love music on their commute. It's a solid performer with some interesting range in practical use across demographics, and is priced lower than other phones in it's class (even including the dual screen case). It has 5g, a huge battery, and performs well - just didn't get much love this year (and i don't mean negative reviews, i mean the big reviewers didn't give it a review)

This list is great... if your rich or have spare $400+ for a phone.  Can we get the same list but for phones under 300/400?  For example, the best budget/power phone at ~$200 would be Moto G Power, imo.  Every phone on this list is as expensive as a decent desktop or laptop computer.

Everything chosen is inherently subjective - to the point that a winner was a smartphone launched only in China (which is out of reach for the majority of people) and an honorable mention just for India. There are lots of great phones this year that didn't even get a mention (Sony should be called out for their sweet Xperia 1 II and lousy time-to-market after the announcement and LG arguably can beat the winner of the year at the same price point and has better specs, while Motorola and Lenovo had a forgettable year, at the level of the Note 20 bust - not to mention lots of Xiaomi, Oppo and Samsung lower end phones - who cares about these phones that outsell the big guns, right?).

Still, this was a great viewing experience. Thanks MKBHD! I'll wait for the full Escobar piece, when it's done.

So, I'll put my opinions about price ranges.

<$10 - cheap feature phones. For really poor people.
$10-$30 - better feature phones. For older generation who doesn't want to deal with a smartphone.

$30-$100 - college kid who wants a smartphone, but has do squeeze out with whatever his parents give him.
$100-$250 - most people who can afford a smartphone would choose something to match their use here.

$250-$800 - fairly rich people, who want a flagship expirience for once. Will switch back to cheaper phones after it gets stolen.

>$800 - for crazy rich people who don't care what things cost...

I would like to thank the whole reviewer community for slapping Sammy on the wrist over the price and specs of the Note20. Without how badly panned that phone got this year, we would not have seen the amazing black friday deals that were had on this phone! I was able to pick mine up for a nice even $500 on Google Fi over the black friday weekend, and could not be happier! While $1k (or $1.2k for the 5G edition that I picked up) is absolutely ridiculous for the midrange device that it is, I feel like $500 was an absolute steal of a deal. And coming from an ancient Pixel3XL, this is one of the largest generational leaps in performance and quality that I have ever seen.
And yeah... it does not have the high refresh display. But at the same time the 3XL could barely do 20-30fps most of the time, so getting a full 60fps is still a massive improvement. 120Hz will just have to be something to look forward to in 3 years when updates stop coming and I upgrade again.

Marques I have 2 questions

:
1. In the “Best Camera Award” shouldn’t you also consider the effect of the social media platforms picture uploading (like in the blind smartphone test) because usually people upload their pictures and videos on social media after a trip or something?

2. Are you doing a bottom-up analysis for the awards (eg. You think of a smartphone and you say “yeah this needs an award”) or a top-down where you think of the category and then you find the smartphones?

First, the social media platforms are intrinsically biased(Ex. Snapchat was made just for iPhones). It doesn't even take pictures from the actual cameras on Android devices. They screenshot through the viewfinder. Others use horrific compression algorithms just to drastically shrink the size of the photo. This award show is basically for, and about what the manufacturers produce each year. Hence why he talks to them as well as us, the viewer throughout the video.
Secondly, if you've watched previous years smart phone awards(you still can on his channel). It's obvious he does the latter, top down approach. The format has always been the same. Award/category, then the winner, and honorable mentions.

My genuine interest for the fordable phones this year have been slowly but strongly increased, to the point that if the quality, experience and design keeps improving I will get my self a fordable phone next year.

The Samsung Z Flip always brings back the nostalgic feel in me, I had a "flipable" phone back in the days when they where a real thing 😄 and I have a friend that is using the first version of the Z Flip and she is pleased with it.
But it is the Samsung Fold that is the most eye catching for me. I hope that they can improve on what they have and keep making smart design choices, if so then the next version of this might be my next smartphone.

About one of your "shoutouts": I bought the M51 just for the battery life, and it lived up to my expectations. It's a 3 day phone for me, but i do not game on my phone at all. Best part is, they managed to build a well rounded phone around the large battery. Would definitely recommend to anyone who needs a massive battery in their phone (at least for people who live in the regions it's sold in).

@Kolyamba fair enough. Though, it depends on every person's use case. I don't need to take a lot of photos daily, so the shooters on this along with a Gcam port is enough to get decent pics. And tbh, the default Samsung camera app is not bad either.

I'd like to respectfully disagree with your opinion of Galaxy M51. I wouldn't call this a "well rounded" device, considering it's lackluster software, espesially in camera department. Also, this model lacks Carrier Aggregation (in Russia, at the very least), despite the fact that Snapdragon 730G supports it "out of the box". Keeping in mind the competition, M in Galaxy M series seems to stand for "mediocre", and the phone itself seems to be specifically desinged to impress with it's specs/price ratio whilst not quite translating it to actual user experience. Kinda tossing this out to balance your positive view of M51 to give some food for thought for would-be-buyers out there. Whoever reads this, have a nice day!

@Adnan Anwar literally the first thing that you find when searching it: Because fast charging means that you use charge cycles (from 0% to 100%) faster, which in turn reduces the life of the battery. Because the fast charging generates more heat which is bad for the battery

@Milán Kingma Unless there's some technical flaw with your battery or charger electronics, however, using a fast charger won't do your phone's battery any long-term damage. ... It's true that when talking about design, it is all objective. For me personally, i think the iPhone, after 3 gens finally getting a new design would've been more deserved. I love the flat and more boxy design. But i also like the Samsung's boxy design. As far as foldable's go, the Z-flip still has my heart 😎 The Microsoft book thing is cool but isn't really a foldable, more like two screens that you can close. A foldable for me is one screen that you then can fold! I did like that Xiaomi phone as well with that chrome, did reming me a bit of the 90's where even some of my friends scooters were chrome. 😂 So i think those would be my picks for sure. As far as budget phone comes, well, i don't buy a new phone every year, so when i buy a phone i always buy one expensive phone and try to go as long as possibly can. IE, i bought the iPhone X back in 2017 and i'm still rocking that one. So it's 3yrs+ at this point. It's still going strong, the only thing is that the battery starts to degrade, but except from that, i still love the design, i bought the white/silver combo with 256GB which, back then was a lot compare to 512GB nowadays. So, budget phones for me, i don't really care. I was hoping to buy that new iPhone this year but since they didn't got 120hz display and 5G isn't really available yet, i just didn't care, i mean i love the new design very much but only buying a new phone for its new design, just... Best compact phone: iPhone 12 mini(Winner), Samsung Galaxy Z Flip 2(Runner up)
Best camera phone: iPhone 12 Pro Max(Winner), Google Pixel 5(Runner up), Asus Zen phone 7 Pro(Shout-out to blind smartphone camera test winner)
Best battery: ASUS ROG Phone 3(Winner), POCO M3 & Samsung M51(Shout-out's)
Best phone design: Samsung Galaxy Note 20 Ultra(Winner), Huawei p40 pro(Shout-out), Microsoft Surface Duo(Special mention), Xiaomi Mi Mix Alpha (Crazy design recognition)
Best budget phone: Google Pixel 4A(Winner), iPhone SE (Runner up), OnePlus Nord(Shout-out)
Biggest bust: Samsung Galaxy Note 20(Winner), Escobar Fold 2(Honorable mention)
Most improved phone: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2(Winner), Google Pixel 5(Honorable mention)
Phone of the year 2020: Samsung Galaxy S20 FE(Winner), OnePlus 8 Pro(Special mention)

The S20 FE doesn't have an actual proximity sensor, it has a virtual one!!! No tech reviewers are mentioning this, and I didn't mention it in my review either (you don't notice it within the first few weeks of using a phone) so if you walk with the phone it will turn itself on because it doesn't have a physical sensor to detect if it's near your face.. Also, there are tons of people having touch issues.

You can have all the specs in the world but if you don't even put a proximity sensor in your phone, it's a fail. I did review this and I thought the same thing as you, I didn't even give it second thought, but after much testing I can say the S20 FE is one of the biggest smartphone fails. This isn't something a normal reviewer would know since they only test phones for 1-2 weeks, so just a heads up!

Smartphone Awards 2020! - The Best of Smartphones in 2020!
🏆 Winners / Runner Up 🏆

1. Best Big Smartphone - Xiaomi Mi 10 Ultra / Samsung Galaxy Note 20 Ultra
2. Best Compact Phone - iPhone 12 Pro Mini / Samsung Galaxy Z Flip 2
3. Best Camera Phone - iPhone 12 Pro Max / Pixel 5
4. Best Battery Phone - Asus ROG Phone 3 / Poco M3
5. Best Phone Design - Samsung Galaxy Note 20 Ultra / Huawei P40 Pro
6. Best Budget Phone - Google Pixel 4a / OnePlus Nord
7. Bust of the Year - Samsung Galaxy Note 20 / Escobar Fold 2
8. Most Improved Phone - Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 / Pixel 5
9. Smartphone of the Year - Samsung Galaxy S20 FE / OnePlus 8 Pro


Total Awards Winners & Runner Ups Tonight:

Samsung - 5

OnePlus - 2
Xiaomi - 1

Let me explain my situation. My salary is 90K USD per year, and believe it or not I use "Poco F2 Pro". I love the simple design, flagship processor, RAM, storage, etc., It has the Electric Purple color. I went to a store nearby and the lady at the billing noticed the color and asked me what phone is it. I said it's Poco. She looked at me as if I am homeless or broke AF to use a Chinese android phone and laughed at me. I laughed and came out :)

People have to understand buying an iPhone doesn't make you rich. I mean why is she working at a billing counter with an iPhone for 10$ an hour? Right? It's about the User Experience, Security of software, frequent updates, and I can get the same on Android too. Why should you look at an android phone so cheap?

For this only reason, I am not buying an iPhone ever not because its a great phone but to laugh back at people who think Android phones are shit

Best Budget Phone should go to the Xiaomi Mi10 T Series, especially the Lite version:

- 120 Hz IPS HDR 10 screen (with way better screen to body ratio) vs 60Hz Oled in the Pixel 4A.
- Snapdragon 750G vs Snapdragon 730G in the Pixel 4A .
- 4800 mAh battery + 33 W charging vs 3140 mAh + 18 W charging in the Pixel 4A.
- Headphone jack, IR blaster, ultra wide lens, micro SD slot & glass back vs only headphone jack in the Pixel 4A.
All that for less than $300 USD. It just CRUSHES the Pixel 4A. A good camera & a clean OS are important, but the numbers just don't lie.


Also, it's really beyond my mind that the iPhone SE gets so much mentions: it's an outdated piece of tech!. I understand that there is still certain market for that phone (grandpas & grandmas), but NO TECH ENTHUSIAST ON EARTH SHOULD BE PRAISING THE iPHONE SE, PERIOD! It's 720p! Come on, y'all! It's 2020, not 2012.

Pixel 5 is actually way better than Pixel 4 because the battery life is nearly twice as good. Pixel 4 battery was trash. The phone is also a much more pure experience of Android, having no squeeze feature or radar sensors. The front display is also much better with UNIFORM bezels (only Android phone to come out with iPhone X level uniformity on the front) and a holepunch selfie cam. The display is also higher grade, being brighter and having better colors. With how pure and basic an experience the Pixel 5 offers, the 765G results in virtually identical performance to the 855 in the Pixel 4. Plus, you get 5G. All at a far more reasonable asking price at launch.
